usc/8/1324a/note

text.#text:
A State or local government may not
				prohibit a person or other entity from verifying the employment authorization
				of new hires or current employees through E-Verify.

A person or other entity that participates
				in E-Verify may not be held liable under any Federal, State, or local law for
				any employment-related action taken with respect to the wrongful termination of
				an individual in good faith reliance on information provided through
				E-Verify.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended to read as follows:

allowing the
				individual to contest the finding; and

not taking
				adverse action against the individual if the individual chooses to contest the
				finding.

The person or other entity may verify the employment
				eligibility of an individual through E-Verify before the individual is hired,
				recruited, or referred if the individual consents to such verification. If an
				employer receives a tentative nonconfirmation for an individual, the employer
				shall comply with procedures prescribed by the Secretary, including—

The person or other entity shall verify the
				employment eligibility of an individual through E-Verify not later than 3 days
				after the date of the hiring, recruitment, or referral, as the case may
				be.

short-title.#tail:

text.#text:
E-Verify shall be designed and
				operated—

to maximize its
				reliability and ease of use by employers;

to insulate and
				protect the privacy and security of the underlying information;

to register any
				times when E-Verify is unable to receive inquiries;

to allow for
				auditing use of the system to detect fraud and identify theft;

to preserve the
				security of the information in all of the system by—

developing
				capabilities to detect anomalies in the use of the system that may indicate
				potential fraud or misuse of the system; and
